channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: NHS 111 'missed chances to save baby'
item.description: NHS England promises to learn lessons after a one year old died of sepsis which was not diagnosed when his mother called the 111 helpline or by GPs.

item.title: 999 crews 'should share control rooms'
item.description: Police, fire and ambulance services in England should share control rooms to improve their response to 999 calls, a Home Office minister says.

item.title: Online 'overtakes TV' for youngsters
item.description: Young people spend more time online than watching television, and Netflix is more popular than conventional channels, according to a survey.

item.title: Denmark to vote on migrant assets bill
item.description: The Danish parliament will vote on a highly controversial proposal to confiscate asylum seekers' valuables to pay for their upkeep.

item.title: Downpours and gales as UK storm begins
item.description: Heavy rain and strong winds have hit parts of the UK as the "remnants" of the storm that brought severe blizzards to the US arrives in the country.

item.title: Act over 'G4S abuse', government urged
item.description: The government is urged to put measures in place at a young offenders' unit following allegations staff assaulted teenage boys.

item.title: Mental health 'serious incidents' rise
item.description: More than 8,000 serious incidents were reported by mental health trusts in England last year - an increase of more than a third over a two-year period.

item.title: Anti-abortion film-makers face charges
item.description: A Texas grand jury clears Planned Parenthood of misconduct after the abortion provider was accused of selling foetal body parts for profit.

item.title: Asylum centre stabbing shocks Sweden
item.description: Sweden's prime minister describes as a "terrible crime" the stabbing of a female employee at a centre for young asylum seekers.

item.title: One in five home cover claims rejected
item.description: More than one in five home insurance claims are unsuccessful owing, in part, to the complexity of policies.

item.title: Tesco knowingly delayed payments
item.description: Tesco "knowingly delayed paying money to suppliers in order to improve its own financial position", the supermarket ombudsman has found.

item.title: New Beatrix Potter story discovered
item.description: A story written by Beatrix Potter more than 100 years ago is to be published for the first time in September, illustrated by Quentin Blake.

item.title: 'Hundreds' claim £33m lottery ticket
item.description: Hundreds of people come forward to claim they bought a winning National Lottery ticket, worth £33m, which has yet to be identified.

item.title: VIDEO: Mother: I touched him but he didn't move
item.description: The mother of William Mead describes the moment she reached into his cot and discovered he was dead when she "touched his arm and he was cold".

item.title: VIDEO: Another record-breaking year for Apple?
item.description: Computing giant Apple is expected to publish another record-breaking set of earning figures, but its stock price falls.

item.title: VIDEO: Scalextric cars get tablet upgrade
item.description: Rory goes hands-on with some of the latest toys and potential best-sellers at an exhibition in London.

item.title: VIDEO: Recreating Dad's Army's home front
item.description: The town of Bridlington is housing the set for the Dad's Army film that premieres in London on Tuesday evening.

item.title: VIDEO: Who is the cat in 'new' Potter book?
item.description: It has been more than 40 years since any new Beatrix Potter tales have been published. But that is about to change.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Snow drones' film US blizzard scenes
item.description: Drone footage captures some of the scenes following the snow storm that gripped many parts of the United States.

item.title: VIDEO: Are 'evil spirits' causing fires in Egypt?
item.description: A village in northern Egypt has been gripped by panic after dozens of houses were burnt in a series of mysterious fires.

item.title: VIDEO: Weather forecast for the UK
item.description: Weather forecast for the UK

item.title: Google tax deal comes under spotlight
item.description: Google's tax deal with revenue and customs, two notable deaths, and Lotto jackpot claims make headlines.

item.title: Is the mighty iPhone in decline?
item.description: After a huge 2015, Apple's 2016 may not be quite so plain sailing, writes Dave Lee.

item.title: Stephen Hawking’s Reith Lecture: Annotated transcript
item.description: A transcript of Prof Stephen Hawking's first Reith Lecture annotated by BBC science editor David Shukman

item.title: Was Salim Benghalem the plotter behind Paris attacks?
item.description: US-based terrorism research group TRAC identifies Frenchman Salim Benghalem as the real mastermind behind the Paris atrocities that claimed 130 lives.

item.title: A tax deal in the hand is worth two in the bush
item.description: We'd all like to cut a deal with the taxman, but why is it only the big guys who are given the chance?

item.title: Van Gaal did not offer to resign
item.description: Manchester United boss Louis van Gaal did not offer to resign at the weekend, despite reports to the contrary.

item.title: England slip to defeat in final Test
item.description: South Africa bowl England out for 101 to win the final Test in Centurion by 280 runs, but the tourists take the series 2-1.

item.title: Williams sees off Sharapova again
item.description: Serena Williams beats Maria Sharapova to reach the Australian Open semi-finals, while Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic both win.

item.title: Ashton to appeal against 10-week ban
item.description: Chris Ashton will appeal against a 10-week ban that would rule him out of England's entire Six Nations campaign.

item.title: European markets fall as Asia tumbles
item.description: European markets have taken fright after another slide in Asia on Tuesday, as oil fell back under $30 a barrel.

item.title: Dixons Carphone to close 134 stores
item.description: Dixons Carphone plans to merge the remaining PC World and Currys shops

item.title: EU vote: Ethnic minorities 'could be key'
item.description: Black and ethnic minority voters are more Eurosceptic than people assume and campaigners for Britain to leave the EU should seek their support, according to UKIP.

item.title: PM and Merkel agree progress made on EU
item.description: PM David Cameron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel speak on the phone and agree progress has been made on Britain's renegotiation with the EU, Number 10 says.

item.title: Pregnant Brits told rethink Zika travel
item.description: Pregnant Britons are being advised to reconsider travel to areas where Zika virus outbreaks are happening.

item.title: Recovery position 'a must for children'
item.description: Doctors say unconscious infants and children should be put in the recovery position, after a study finds dangerous manoeuvres are sometimes used instead.

item.title: Faith school places objections limited
item.description: Secularist campaign groups are to be stopped from making "vexatious complaints" against the admissions systems of individual faith schools.

item.title: Schools 'must offer apprenticeships'
item.description: Schools in England will have to give as much time to vocational routes as academic subjects in an effort to help students who want to land apprenticeships.

item.title: Toy Fair: Retro toys tipped for growth
item.description: Scalextric and Thunderbirds are among the retro toys that the toy industry hopes will drive growth this year.

item.title: Council staff punished for net abuse
item.description: There was a rise in the number of council workers suspended last year after being accused of breaking social media rules.

item.title: Hubble successor maintains course
item.description: James Webb, the space telescope that will take over from Hubble, is reaching some key milestones in its preparation for launch in 2018.

item.title: Lanky bird's killer kick quantified
item.description: The secretary bird kicks snakes to death with a strike that packs five times the bird's own weight in a fraction of a second, scientists say.

item.title: Kit Harington back on stage as Faustus
item.description: Game of Thrones star Kit Harington is learning the art of stage illusion for his new West End play, Doctor Faustus.

item.title: JK Rowling to receive human rights award
item.description: JK Rowling is be honoured with to receive a prestigious award from the literary and human rights group Pen America.

item.title: How does the lottery investigate damaged tickets?
item.description: A woman says her winning lottery ticket got damaged in the wash - but what does the lottery do about such claims?

item.title: Why do sperm whales wash up on beaches?
item.description: Pods of young male sperm whales are now regularly stranded along Britain's coast. Why?

item.title: Inside the maternity bags of expectant mothers
item.description: Inside the maternity bags of mothers-to-be around the world.

item.title: Swimming with elephants and sharks
item.description: Swimming with toxic fish and sexy shrimp

item.title: Why do people put on differing amounts of weight?
item.description: Why do people put on differing amounts of weight?

item.title: Was there a communist witch-hunt at the BBC?
item.description: The man who wanted to root out 'traitors' in Britain

item.title: The job cuts uniting workers in Wales and China
item.description: What do Port Talbot and Hangzhou have in common?

item.title: Calling the new branch of IS – in Afghanistan
item.description: Dialling up the new branch of IS – in Afghanistan

item.title: Do white rappers benefit from 'white privilege'?
item.description: The white rapper who says he has an unfair advantage

item.title: VIDEO: New play tackles the topic of stillbirth
item.description: How can a couple face a great tragedy?

item.title: How to be a better public speaker
item.description: How to overcome a terror of public speaking

item.title: Have we reached peak "peak"?
item.description: Have we reached peak 'peak'?

item.title: Sir Michael Caine's elixir of Youth
item.description: Sir Michael Caine says his life gets better with age
